Award.AwardTitle: ELT Collaborative Research: Perturbation of the Marine Food Web and Extinction During the Oceanic Anoxic Event at the Cenomanian/Turonian Boundary
Award.AbstractNarration:
ELT Collaborative Research: Perturbation of the Marine Food Web and
Extinction during the Oceanic Anoxic Event at the Cenomanian/Turonian
Boundary

by

Timothy Bralower, Penn State University, EAR-1338316
Bradley Sageman, Northwestern University, EAR-1338312
R. Mark Leckie, Univ. Massachusetts, Amherst, EAR-1338317
Julio Sepulveda, MIT, EAR-1338318

ABSTRACT
The expansion of oxygen-deficient waters, known as hypoxia, is occurring seasonally in places such as the Gulf of Mexico as a result of warming and pollution. Hypoxia can affect all marine organisms through the loss of habitat, changes in predator-prey dynamics, and availability of nutrients for primary production. Ocean acidification resulting from the input of anthropogenic CO2 is already impacting the ability of many organisms to grow shells. The geological record contains a series of natural experiments that allow us to address the biological response of the biota to ocean acidification and widespread oxygen deficiency.

The Cenomanian-Turonian boundary (94 million years ago in the middle of the Cretaceous Period), a time interval marked by mass extinction, was also characterized by global oxygen deficiency and likely ocean acidification. Thus, the Cenomanian-Turonian boundary is an excellent ancient model for the impact of anthropogenic activities on marine ecosystems. A superb opportunity exits to explore the impact of oxygen deficiency and ocean acidification during the Cenomanian-Turonian boundary in rock outcrops from the western and southern margins of the US Western Interior Seaway. In Utah, rocks contain original ammonite aragonite as well as remains of large marine reptiles. In Texas, British Petroleum has made available a unique core and exclusive access to outcrop sections. Back-hoeing of rock outcrops will unearth pristine fossil shells suitable for reconstruction of ancient environmental conditions using geological proxies, and coring will provide rocks that can be studied to determine changes that took place over centuries. The insight gained from the CTB can be applied to other intervals of biotic upheaval in Earth history and will help improve projections of the impacts of human activities, including hypoxia and ocean acidification, on modern ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ELT Collaborative Research: Perturbation of the Marine Food Web and Extinction During the Oceanic Anoxic Event at the Cenomanian/Turonian Boundary

Northwestern scientists contributing to this project were mainly responsbile for the planning and logistics of field work for the study, which involved drilling two new research cores and sampling a nearby outcrop section in southern Utah, and for the analysis of sedimentation in the study interval.  The rationale for sample collection from these sites is that they preserve one of the most expanded and complete records of a remarkable event - the Cenomanian-Turonian Ocean Anoxic Event 2 (OAE2). Triggered by a massive volcanic eruption, OAE2 was a period of intense global warming and climatic instability, widespread depletion of oxygen in marine waters, and significant dispruption of global ecosystems leading to extinction. A major objective of our project has been to improve understanding of the nature and timing of events associated with the onset and progression of OAE2.  For example, ocean acidification, which is believed to have characterized the early phases of the event. 

An important initial accomplishment of the work completed by Northwestern team members has been the development of a highly resolved time scale for the study interval, which allows all subsequent discoveries to be placed in a precise temporal framework. This was achieved through a combination of detailed stratigraphic and geochemical data collection followed by the application of advanced spectral analysis techniques to identify the signature of Milankovitch cycles in the stratigraphic records. The correlation of new radioisotopic age dates into the succession, combined with the astrochronology derived from analysis of Milankovitch cycles, has yielded one of the most finely resolved time scales for OAE2 yet to be constructed. Interestingly, the preservation of such cycles in the proximal offshore sediments was a consequence of sea level changes that were driven by climatic fluctuations modulated by the Earth's orbital cycles (precession, obliquity, eccentricity). During cool climate modes changes in glacial ice volume control such sea level changes, but the OAE2 interval was among the hottest times in Earh history. Identification of sea level cycles with timing similar to glacial cycles, but under hothouse conditions, supports a recently proposed model for ancient sea level change: aquifer eustasy (the storage and release of water from land-based reserviors - streams, lakes, wetlands, and subsurface aquifers). 

These accomplishments, presented in publication that is now in press with the Bulletin of the Geological Society of America (Jones et al., 2018), provide the foundation for further research on changes in environmental conditions and ecosystems that took place during OAE2.
